title: Paul's Journey to Jerusalem
shortSummary: Acts 21 details Paul's determined journey to Jerusalem despite prophetic warnings of imprisonment and suffering. The chapter highlights the tension between Jewish believers and Gentile converts, culminating in Paul's arrest in the temple, setting the stage for his trials. This chapter emphasizes obedience to God's calling and the cost of faithful witness.
timeline: c. AD 57 - Paul's Third Missionary Journey, journey to Jerusalem

keyCharacters.name: Paul
keyCharacters.description: The apostle and missionary who is resolutely traveling to Jerusalem, aware of the dangers ahead, demonstrating faithfulness and courage.

keyCharacters.name: Philip the Evangelist
keyCharacters.description: One of the seven appointed in Acts 6, hosting Paul in Caesarea and father of four daughters who prophesied.

keyCharacters.name: Agabus
keyCharacters.description: A prophet from Judea who foretells Paul's imprisonment by binding his own hands and feet with Paul's girdle.

keyCharacters.name: James
keyCharacters.description: The leader of the Jerusalem church who meets with Paul and advises him on Jewish customs to maintain peace.

definitions.definition: A belt or sash worn around the waist; here used symbolically by Agabus to represent Paul's future binding.
A solemn promise or commitment to God, often involving purification rituals such as shaving the head.
The sacred Jewish place of worship in Jerusalem, central to Jewish religious life and identity.
A message inspired by the Holy Spirit, often foretelling future events or providing divine guidance.

outline.heading: Paul's Voyage and Warning at Tyre
outline.description: Paul and his companions travel through various cities, stopping at Tyre where disciples, through the Spirit, warn Paul not to go to Jerusalem. Despite the warning, Paul remains resolute, illustrating his commitment to God's will.

outline.heading: Stay in Caesarea and Prophetic Warning
outline.description: Paul stays with Philip the evangelist and meets the prophet Agabus, who dramatically predicts Paul's imprisonment. Paul's readiness to suffer and die for Christ underscores his unwavering faith.

outline.heading: Arrival in Jerusalem and Meeting with Church Leaders
outline.description: Paul arrives in Jerusalem, is warmly received, and reports on his ministry among the Gentiles. The leaders advise Paul to participate in purification rites to dispel rumors and maintain unity between Jewish and Gentile believers.

outline.heading: Paul's Arrest in the Temple
outline.description: Despite Paul's efforts to show respect for Jewish law, he is falsely accused of defiling the temple by bringing Gentiles inside. A riot ensues, and Paul is arrested, marking the beginning of his trials and suffering for the gospel.

application: Trust God's guidance even when warnings suggest hardship; obedience may require courage and sacrifice.
Maintain unity in the church by respecting cultural and religious sensitivities without compromising the gospel.
Be prepared to suffer for Christ’s name, following Paul’s example of steadfast faith and willingness to endure hardship.
Pray earnestly for protection and strength when facing opposition or persecution for your faith.

keyVerses.text: Then Paul answered, What mean ye to weep and to break mine heart? for I am ready not to be bound only, but also to die at Jerusalem for the name of the Lord Jesus.
keyVerses.significance: This verse reveals Paul's courageous commitment to God's calling, even in the face of death.

keyVerses.text: And when he was come unto us, he took Paul's girdle, and bound his own hands and feet, and said, Thus saith the Holy Ghost, So shall the Jews at Jerusalem bind the man that owneth this girdle, and shall deliver him into the hands of the Gentiles.
keyVerses.significance: Agabus’ prophecy confirms the divine foreknowledge of Paul's impending suffering and imprisonment.

keyVerses.text: Then Paul took the men, and the next day purifying himself with them entered into the temple, to signify the accomplishment of the days of purification, until that an offering should be offered for every one of them.
keyVerses.significance: Paul’s participation in Jewish purification rites demonstrates his respect for the law and desire to maintain peace within the church.

keyVerses.text: And when he had given him licence, Paul stood on the stairs, and beckoned with the hand unto the people. And when there was made a great silence, he spake unto them in the Hebrew tongue, saying,
keyVerses.significance: Paul’s appeal to the crowd in Hebrew shows his connection to his Jewish heritage and his desire to witness effectively.
